posts.name: Anaxonda
posts.cooked:
After five years of moderate use, my Signal backup is approaching 6 GB.

I enjoy having all my chat history available, but the backup size is very unwieldly. I am reaching the point where I should probably start with a new install, but I wish it would be possible to backup signal without writing everything to a new backup every time.

Whatsapp accomplishes this by separating media from messages, so that many year of message backup is very small. I‚Äôm not sure how hard it would be to have something similar in Signal, and although I would be happy with it I guess it would less secure.

Perhaps an ideal way to have deduplicated backups, like Borg Backup, where files that have already been backed up are not written again. In that way a daily backup would only be a few megabytes, easy to sync with cloud storage.

These are just my thoughts, appreciate if anyone has other ideas.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked: Signals own backup file feature should always keep only two files and overwrite those. Is that any different for you?

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
The local backup system has basically worked the same way for a decade and is unlikely to change because recent commits seem to point to a cloud storage system being in development.

The introduction of PINs and the light functionality of it might‚Äôve been an attempt at a proof-of-concept to ensure it was worth putting the time and resources into further development.
A post was split to a new topic: Can exported media be reimported?

Avitus:

The local backup system has basically worked the same way for a decade and is unlikely to change because recent commits seem to point to a cloud storage system being in development .

This basically forces the signal devs to overhaul backups. No one has enough data-caps to transfer 500mb to 10Gb each night to a cloud storage system. I dont know what they are planning, and how it should work, but the current way is simply incompatible with external storage.

Here is another discussion:

Some form of incremental backup Android Feature Requests
Been meaning to put together a solution using these outside projects but I lost ALOT of steam when SF announced they would move away from SMS integration. I suspect that will be the end of my use for this platform. Hope this is valuable though if someone else wants to pickup the flag.

The backup feature of signal is getting problematic for some users, me including. I have to transfer huge amounts of data regularly, backups take huge amounts of storage space on the device itself (up to 20gb including signal itself) and on external devices aswell. I really hope that they plan on redoing the backup in a way that solves those issues, also in a way that does not require any specific cloud-service.

The community has stepped in a little GitHub - bepaald/signalbackup-tools: Tool to work with Signal Backup files.
However I am worried this is subpar. What I assumed was the most obvious solution (partitioning the backup by years and only keeping the current year on my phone) was too buggy to use because most people are just dumping attachments instead, and while I am working with the community of the project to get that working, it does speak to Whisper Systems‚Äô db design and the chance that a decade down the road when I try to restore a backup to retrieve data I want, that old backup will be unrecognizable to the newest version of signal.
This ideally should be something that is designed into the product and not a modded improvement.

link_counts.title: GitHub - bepaald/signalbackup-tools: Tool to work with Signal Backup files.

posts.cooked:
Your linked tool is amazing for working with backups on desktop devices, but it does not alleviate the issue mentioned here.

The tool relies on the backup already beeing on another device. If you mean that this tool should be used to reduce the size of the signal-database in the android app, this is also really not a solution since it basically means that ‚Äúdataloss‚Äù is ‚Äúrequired‚Äù for sensible backups.

I feel that the signal-devs have to rework how signal creates backups, so that the size issue is solved-by-design and not after a backup has been created. I really do hope to see some improvements.

newhinton:

If you mean that this tool should be used to reduce the size of the signal-database in the android app

No, I agree. This ‚Äúshould be‚Äù something Whisper Devs are iterating on further. I am just pointing out a subpar work around that might help a little until then. And ya, you need a desktop and probably off device storage which are things some users wont have. If Wisper made this feature native it fixes the first, but unless someone invents magic compression you can‚Äôt significantly reduce the size of the backup without reducing the size of the database.

So I am not sure what you are envisioning? At some point you either have to drop older info or drop images and/or video from the live DB.

Partitioning off older data into a backup that is no longer in the live db is the most lossless method I can imagine. If you extract images, you lose the positional data even if you keep the images elsewhere, but you are able to keep a longer live db and text to query.

chaoservices:

So I am not sure what you are envisioning? At some point you either have to drop older info or drop images and/or video from the live DB.

Partitioning off older data into a backup that is no longer in the live db is the most lossless method I can imagine. If you extract images, you lose the positional data even if you keep the images elsewhere, but you are able to keep a longer live db and text to query.

My preferred Implementation would do it the following way:

  1. Split backups into years. Each year is a valid standalone backup.
  2. Split the current year into months. Each month is again a valid standalone backup.
    (Optional) 3. Split the current month into weeks/days. Again, still standalone.

Why?

This should lead to backups beeing incremental. Instead of each backup using 5gb, each year will probably require 300mb to 700mb in filesize, and each month 50-150mb. Since each backup is standalone, we now only need to backup the current month off device. (We also need to copy the ‚Äúold‚Äù data once, and every year we need to pack and copy the ‚Äúlast‚Äù year since it will then be a full year and not a monthly-backup). This greatly reduces bandwith usage since only changing data will be transferred.

Additional benefit: Since each backup is standalone, restoring selectively should be possible. You can create a full backup, delete all the appdata and then only restore the last 6 months to keep the data itself small. There are some issues with that, but none that cant be solved.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
newhinton:

No one has enough data-caps to transfer 500mb to 10Gb each night to a cloud storage system

I mean, WhatsApp only does cloud backup when you‚Äôre on WiFi by default (and that can be changed if you have a large data cap). No reason Signal won‚Äôt implement something similar.
Those two things are incompatible‚Ä¶ you can‚Äôt have independent standalone backups that are incremental. There are things that change that would create conflicts between backups.

Why would this be true? ‚ÄúOld‚Äù data does not ‚Äúchange‚Äù. Therefore you can assume that the year 2018 is ‚Äúfixed‚Äù.

Sure i can delete data from 2018, but there are multiple ways to handle this. Either place a ‚Äúdelete instruction‚Äù in the current months or years backup (so that a restore would delete the message), or you recreate the changed years backup-file. There is a lot of ways this can be done.

Yes, but afaik whatsapp does not have a monolithic backup-file. They seperate media&chats, so that any sync tool can figure out which files need to be backed up, reducing the filesize to the absolute minimum. This is very close to what i would like to see, and the opposite of what signal does at the moment.

(For comparison: The daily copy of whatsapps msgstore-file is roughly 10mb. Granted, my whatsapp message database is only a couple months old, but i have not seen it exceed 100mb and even 3 Year old databases roughly use half of that.)

1. Split backups into years. Each year is a valid standalone backup.

So exactly what I seek to do with the linked tool lol Apologies if I failed to communicate that to you effectively. The biggest problem here though is that Whisper appears to be changing the database scheme as they continue to develop the product. This makes the viability of any backup unpredictable for use a future date and is the biggest failure point in my solution.

but it does not alleviate the issue mentioned here.

Yours does not either. Are you discarding data from the live DB as it is moved into backups? Are you moving the incremental off the device? You point out the depending on another device is problematic, which is a very smart consideration, however without doing so you solution has run into the same problem with space.

10GB live DB
10GB old signal backup

or

10GB live DB
5GB 20xx backup
5GB 20xx+1 backup

It occurs to me that we may be overloading the functionality for backup. The feature we are actually looking for is an archive.
posts.edit_reason: A post was merged in by Herohtar

posts.cooked:
No you are partly correct. It does not reduce overall size. (That cant be done without data-loss anyway, albeit i dont know wether or not signal employs compression in their current backup)

However, it actually alleviates many of the pains with the current implementation. Currently it is basically impossible to regularly backup signal since it always creates X Gb of data. With my changes, the changed data is only a couple of megabytes, which are far easier to sync.

(syncing/moving backups off device is not signals responsibility)

Also:

When each singular year is backed up on its own, in a standalone file, the user can arbitrarily restore data, while still keeping all the files. Lets say i have a full backup from 2015 to 2023, and moved it off device. I can then kill signal, restore signal, and only restore 2017, 2020 and 2023 by deleting all the other backups on the device, therefore reducing DB size.

Later, in 2030, i can kill signal, readd the missing database files, and then do a full restore from 2015 to 2030 without loosing a single message. (Assuming the passphrase never changed)

You are probably right, it has quite a few attributes of an archive.

Your tool seems to manage backups AFTER they have been saved to a different device for safekeeping. (or management)

However, what i propose is that the backups are split and organized BEFORE they leave the device. (Even before they are written to disk)

Your tool can allow users to reduce the overall size of their app by restoring a modified backup, but what i would like to see is that signal creates backup files in a sensible size, removing the need for reducing app-size in the first place.
posts.edit_reason: A post was merged in by Herohtar

posts.name: Sebastian
posts.cooked:
Yes, I agree that it would be awesome to have something like an archive, splitted into years. Maybe the signal app could do the archive for the previous year a few days after New Year‚Äôs eve - then many issues with disappearing messages and time zones should be resolved.

At the signal team: I would really like to see something like this! Please don‚Äôt go in a direction where an efficient backup is possible only via a cloud solution.

And an additional wish: It would be awesome to have a tool like signalbackup-tools supported by Signal!

Best greetings,
Sebastian

link_counts.title: GitHub - bepaald/signalbackup-tools: Tool to work with Signal Backup files.

posts.name: Croissant
posts.cooked:
I know that the new encrypted cloud backups will have the incremental feature, but I assume the local backup improvements will include that as well, see here:

Public Signal Backups Testing Call for Testing
For what it‚Äôs worth, I believe that the Signal Backups purchase can be shared with a Family via Google Pay (I don‚Äôt know iOS enough to know the equivalent over there). I do not know how many devices we configured it to allow, but it‚Äôs more than one I don‚Äôt really see it like that. Running a service like this is expensive, and we‚Äôve priced it to be competitive with other storage offerings. You could imagine a world where we have more granular tiers, but that puts a lot of burden‚Ä¶

Croissant:

I assume the local backup improvements will include that as well

Yes, Greyson confirmed that local backups would be getting the same improvements.
